G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 and 21,.proposition: The Worcester District Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 and 21, because the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limit of the District Court and because this is a civil action in tort seeking money damages.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 and G.L. c. 218, § 19, because the cause of action arose in Worcester County and the Premises where the incident occurred is located within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 and G.L. c. 218, § 19, because the cause of action arose in Worcester County and the Premises where the incident occurred is located within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, as the owner and person in control of the Premises at 123 Maple Street, owed a duty to lawful visitors, including Plaintiff, to exercise reasonable care to keep the property and its common areas, including the sidewalk and access path, in a reasonably safe condition, and to protect lawful visitors against reasonably foreseeable risks of harm.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.support_reasoning: Mounsey abolishes the common-law invitee/licensee distinction in Massachusetts and imposes on occupiers a general duty of reasonable care to lawful entrants. While the provided excerpt is only a concurrence and focuses on the treatment of trespassers, the case as a whole stands for the proposition that an owner/occupier owes lawful visitors a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep premises, including common areas, reasonably safe against foreseeable risks. The specific address and facts (123 Maple Street, sidewalk/path) are not in the opinion, but the general duty proposition is consistent with the holding.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.relevant_excerpt: We now hold that the common law distinctions between licensees and invitees are abolished in this Commonwealth. The proper test of the occupier’s liability in cases of this sort is whether in the management of his property he has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others… The occupier of land owes to all lawful visitors a duty to act with reasonable care to prevent injury to them.

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, as the owner and person in control of the Premises at 123 Maple Street, owed a duty to lawful visitors, including Plaintiff, to exercise reasonable care to keep the property and its common areas, including the sidewalk and access path, in a reasonably safe condition, and to protect lawful visitors against reasonably foreseeable risks of harm.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly recites the general Massachusetts rule that an owner or possessor of land owes lawful visitors a common-law duty of reasonable care to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of unreasonable dangers. Although the case ultimately holds that this duty does not extend to requiring the defendant to alter an adjacent state highway, the stated general duty to lawful visitors on the premises (including common areas) is directly consistent with the proposition cited. The proposition is accurate so long as it is not read to extend to requiring control or alteration of a public highway beyond the premises.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors… This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware. … Although a landowner or possessor typically is not held to any duty with respect to public highways adjacent to or crossing his land, he must exercise reasonable care in the use of his land so as not to injure a traveler on the highway.”

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes a duty on property owners and persons in control of property to act with reasonable care regarding snow and ice conditions, and to treat snow and ice like any other dangerous condition on the property.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion directly abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and expressly holds that hazards from snow and ice are subject to the same reasonable-care duty as all other property hazards. It states that property owners and persons responsible for maintaining property owe lawful visitors a duty to act as a reasonable person with respect to snow and ice, thereby treating snow and ice like any other dangerous condition.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now abolish the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, and apply to all hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation of reasonable care that a property owner owes to lawful visitors regarding all other hazards.” … “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances….’”

*Normandin v. Town of Belchertown*, 468.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes a duty on property owners and persons in control of property to act with reasonable care regarding snow and ice conditions, and to treat snow and ice like any other dangerous condition on the property.
*Normandin v. Town of Belchertown*, 468.support_reasoning: The excerpted opinion concerns Massachusetts’ electronic surveillance statute and the scope of the one‑party consent exception under G.L. c. 272, § 99. It does not discuss premises liability, snow and ice, or duties of property owners or persons in control of property. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the proposition about a duty of reasonable care regarding snow and ice conditions.

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.proposition: Defendant’s duty of reasonable care toward Plaintiff and other lawful visitors is consistent with the general negligence principles in Massachusetts.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.support_reasoning: The court explicitly frames the negligence claim in terms of general Massachusetts negligence principles, reiterating that every actor owes a duty of reasonable care to avoid foreseeable physical harm to others. It then holds that this homeowner owed a duty of reasonable care to the police officer as a foreseeable victim, treating that duty as an application of the general negligence framework (duty, breach, causation, damages) rather than as some special or sui generis duty. Thus, the opinion supports the proposition that the defendant’s duty of reasonable care toward the plaintiff and other lawful visitors is consistent with general negligence principles in Massachusetts.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care… We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ … In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner… has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured. This duty is owed to, inter alia, a law enforcement officer shot by the person granted unsupervised access, because the officer is a foreseeable victim….”

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.proposition: Defendant’s duty of reasonable care toward Plaintiff and other lawful visitors is consistent with the general negligence principles in Massachusetts.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.support_reasoning: The opinion does recite the general elements of a negligence claim and references Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 and a Massachusetts tort treatise, which reflect general negligence principles. However, the court expressly declines to decide whether the defendant owed any duty of care to the plaintiffs and instead affirms summary judgment solely on the element of causation. Because the existence and scope of a duty toward lawful visitors is left unresolved, the case does not actually establish or affirm the proposition about the defendant’s duty.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.relevant_excerpt: With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). … Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment.

*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 168\.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act after receiving actual notice from tenants that the sidewalk had become dangerously icy constitutes a clear breach of her duty of reasonable care.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 168\.support_reasoning: The case concerns a defective porch railing on leased premises and holds that a landlord owes a duty of reasonable care to tenants’ guests for negligent maintenance of rented areas. It does not involve snow, ice, sidewalks, or notice from tenants about an icy condition, nor does it analyze a landlord’s breach based on failure to act after such notice. The proposition about icy sidewalks and actual notice is therefore not supported by this opinion, which is focused on abolishing the old no-duty rule for defects on demised premises generally.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 168\.relevant_excerpt: “In particular, a landlord should not be liable in negligence unless he knew or reasonably should have known of the defect and had a reasonable opportunity to repair it.… General Laws c. 186, § 19, requires most landlords to exercise reasonable care to correct an unsafe condition of which the tenant or a code enforcement agency has given him notice. If a landlord fails to correct the condition within a reasonable time, the tenant or any person rightfully on the premises has a tort action against the landlord for injuries sustained.”

*Lyon v. Morphew*, 424 Mass. 828, 831\u2.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act after receiving actual notice from tenants that the sidewalk had become dangerously icy constitutes a clear breach of her duty of reasonable care.
*Lyon v. Morphew*, 424 Mass. 828, 831\u2.support_reasoning: The case does not involve icy sidewalks, tenants, or a landowner’s duty after actual notice of an icy condition; it concerns whether certain hospital employees owed a personal duty regarding roof railings and contractor safety. The court in fact emphasizes limits on duties and declines to impose additional safety obligations absent a common-law or statutory duty. It therefore neither discusses nor supports the proposition that a defendant’s failure to act after tenant notice of dangerous ice is a clear breach of reasonable care.
*Lyon v. Morphew*, 424 Mass. 828, 831\u2.relevant_excerpt: “There is no duty to protect lawful visitors from dangers obvious to persons of ordinary intelligence. … The hazardous nature of ascending a roof is readily apparent to a reasonably intelligent person… We have never recognized a common law duty of building owners to place or maintain fall protection safety devices on roofs. … Absent a statutory or common law duty, the director and assistant director may not be held individually liable for failing to replace the safety railing prior to the accident.”

*Papadopoulos*, 457 Mass. at 384\u201385.proposition: By failing to take reasonable steps to remove, treat, or warn about the ice condition after receiving actual notice and having ample time to act, Defendant acted unreasonably and fell below the standard of care required of a reasonable property owner in like circumstances.

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. at.proposition: The type of harm suffered by Plaintiff—slip‑and‑fall injuries to his back caused by a dangerous ice condition on a walkway—is a reasonably foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s failure to exercise reasonable care in maintaining the sidewalk.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Defendant’s conduct and omissions constituted negligence under Massachusetts common law and under the general negligence principles reflected in G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence framework).

*Alvarez v. Seadside, Inc.*, 82 Mass. Ap.raw_text: *Alvarez v. Seadside, Inc.*, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 294, 297–98 (2012)
*Alvarez v. Seadside, Inc.*, 82 Mass. Ap.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant is liable to Plaintiff for all damages proximately caused by her negligence, including medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and other consequential damages.

*Jones v. Boykan*, 464 Mass. 285, 294\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant is liable to Plaintiff for all damages proximately caused by her negligence, including medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and other consequential damages.
*Jones v. Boykan*, 464 Mass. 285, 294\u2.support_reasoning: The excerpt concerns procedural limits on Rule 60(b) relief and the finality of judgments, not the substantive scope of damages recoverable in a negligence action. It does not discuss what categories of damages (medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, consequential damages) are available under Massachusetts negligence law. Accordingly, it provides no support for the claimed proposition about the measure of damages.
*Jones v. Boykan*, 464 Mass. 285, 294\u2.relevant_excerpt: "If the defendants wanted to be heard on damages, they should have appeared at the hearing to assess damages. Failing that, they could have appealed the judgment. They did not appeal. As the court notes, rule 60 is not a substitute for the normal appellate process. See Amerada Hess Corp. v. Garabedian, 416 Mass. 149, 156-157 (1993); Pentucket Manor Chronic Hosp. v. Rate Setting Comm’n, 394 Mass. 233, 236 (1985)."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B or other applicable provisions;
